thread.title: Sydney weather temperatures drop by 10C in just 10 minutes
thread.title_full: Sydney weather temperatures drop by 10C in just 10 minutes | Daily Mail Online

author: Cindy Tran for Daily Mail Australia
title: Sydney weather temperatures drop by 10C in just 10 minutes
text:
As Sydney sweats through another sizzling day, the hot spell may well be over as temperatures plummet after reaching nearly 40 degrees.
The cool change has finally arrived, with temperatures already dropping by more than 10 degrees in the city within 10 minutes on Tuesday.
But despite southerly winds bringing relief to Sydney, an extreme heatwave will return by the weekend.
The city has sweltered through six nights in January - the warmest on record this month for Australia's east coast - after temperatures failed to drop below 24 degrees.
Earlier on Tuesday, Sydney was recorded as the hottest city in the country - as Brisbane enjoys a sunny 30C while temperatures of 22C is forecast for Melbourne.
The rest of the country are in for a wet day, with heavy rain forecast for Perth, showers for Hobart, Darwin and Canberra while Adelaide will see clouds.
Sydney has been sweating through another sizzling day as temperatures hit 40C on Tuesday
The city has sweltered through six nights in January - the warmest on record this month
Sydney will be the hottest city in the country on Tuesday, Brisbane will enjoy a sunny 30C while temperatures of 22C has been forecast for Melbourne
On Monday night, temperatures didn't drop below 27.4C in Sydney's northern suburb of Terrey Hills, as Penrith hovered at 30C at midnight.
Beachgoers will enjoy 39C until the southerly cool change is set to arrive from midday, with temperatures dropping by more than 10C by 4pm.
The cool change will hit the city by 1pm and temperatures will drop to about 24C by the evening, said a Bureau of Meteorology spokesman on Tuesday.
A total fire ban has been issued for the Greater Sydney Region and the Greater Hunter, with Tuesday's dry and windy conditions a concern for NSW firefighters.
Sydney recorded one of its hottest nights on record with the mercury hitting 31C at midnight on Monday. Pictured, Beachgoers cool off at Bondi as temperatures reached 36C
The city has sweltered through six nights in January - the warmest on record this month
Despite Sydney enjoying the glorious sunshine, just 22C has been forecast for Melbourne
Sydneysiders flocking to Bondi Beach (pictured) on Tuesday, as temperatures set for 40C
The cool change on Tuesday afternoon will be short-lived though as extreme heat is expected to return by the weekend (pictured of North Bondi Beach on Tuesday morning)
The cool change on Tuesday afternoon will be short-lived though as extreme heat is expected to return by the weekend.
This year already Sydney has sweltered above six nights above 24C, says the weather bureau, and the city has recorded eight days of 35C or higher.
The record is nine days.
The NSW Rural Fire Service is on alert amid challenging conditions on Tuesday.
Vegetation is already dry and hot and windy conditions can become unpredictable.
'We need people to be very vigilant, report all fires to Triple-Zero straight away,' said RFS spokesman Greg Allan.
A wind change on Thursday could bring temporary relief, but the change will be shallow and any relief is likely to be short-lived with the heat building up again on Friday
Sydney will be the hottest city in the country on Tuesday while Brisbane will bask in 30C
A beachgoer overlooking the sparkling blue water at Sydney's famous Bondi Icebergs
Beachgoers will enjoy 39C until the southerly cool change is set to arrive on Tuesday midday
A cool change with southerly winds expected to bring relief to Sydney from 1pm on Tuesday
While there's no total fire ban for Sydney, residents are flocking to the city's beaches
Sydney will be the hottest city in the country on Tuesday while Brisbane will bask in 30C
